sub_topic: Analysis of the purity of a substance using melting point determination
message_1: What is the percent purity of a sample of aspirin if its melting point range is found to be 131-135°C, compared to the known melting point range of pure aspirin at 135-136°C?
message_2:
To determine the percent purity of a sample of aspirin based on its melting point range, we can use the following formula:

Percent Purity = [(Observed Melting Point - Impure Melting Point) / (Pure Melting Point - Impure Melting Point)] × 100

However, in this case, we only have the observed melting point range (131-135°C) and the pure melting point range (135-136°C). We do not have a specific impure melting point to use in the formula. Therefore, we cannot accurately calculate the percent purity of the aspirin sample using the given information.

It is important to note that a lower melting point range than the pure aspirin range indicates the presence of impurities in the sample, but we cannot quantify the exact percent purity without more information.
